I love you and your videos Natalie, but this one is a bit naive in my opinion, especially considering people with eating disorders - that part after eating 2 and a half big macs could be a real trigger for people with bulimia and compulsive eating. I've been reading more and more about that and something that many psychiatrists, therapists and nutritionists have been enforcing is that restrictive diets do not work - in fact, they could make everything worse. People who go under a restrictive diet have 95% of chance to regain the weight they lost or even gain more than they used to. It could lead to eating disorders like anorexia, bulimia and this new orthorexia thing too. There's a huge movement talking about how we should reconnect to our bodies, feelings and necessities to understand what is to be hungry and what is to be emotionally eating. People who lived their lives always on a diet have difficulty to know when they are truly hungry and how hungry they are. The same goes when it's about satisfaction - they don't know when the meal was enough or when to stop because you are satisfied. Your ability to stop at the second and a half burger is like an achievement for people with compulsion. It's a very complicated subject and I love that you try to change the meaning of obesity, but I don't know if I agree with your solution. Your other video about beauty was beautiful and precise, your arguments evolved a lot too. So it would be great to see if you could talk about body neutrality and intuitive eating for instance and what are your views upon this movement against body shaming (being it for its weight, its ethnicity, its gender or anything). Have you heard about it? I would love to hear more from you. I have been reading Naomi Wolf and she has great insights about thinness and beauty standards as an strategy to control women (and here I consider any women, trans or cis) from her bodies since our minds were set free. Anyways, love you, keep up your amazing work!

Part of the problem with the obesity crisis is the normalisation of obesity and being overweight.  We're now expecting magazines and television to embrace 'body-type diversity', we praise magazines who feature obese people on their covers (and conversely condemn those who don't do this) and we're telling people to love your body how matter what. All this contributes to the normalisation of obesity.  We're told we should see more overweight and obese people in the media because this represents real body shapes. But the fact that so many people (perhaps most) are now overweight or obese isn't a reason to promote, and therefore normalise this body type.  Suppose most people had missing or discoloured teeth. Would that be a reason to see more bad teeth in the media, so we're reflecting what's real? Would anyone advocate for this? Of course not!  Why would an overweight or obese person feel a need to loose weight if their weight and body is considered normal. If they're just like everyone else, where's the urgency? The answer is there isn't any urgency and therefore we find ourself exactly where we are now: an obesity crisis.  In contrast, if we promote and encourage appropriate body weight, which means not endorsing those who are overweight, and we see less people that are overweight, it should become clearer to society that something must be done sooner when we do start to gain too much weight.  None of this means we should shame anyone or make them feel bad, nor does it mean we shouldn't recognise the various reasons why people gain weight and the difficulties in losing it. But not doing these things doesn't mean we should embrace ideas, actions or policies that normalise or even promote obesity.

I feel like your point of 'I don't think it's any of my goddamn business what other people do with their bodies' is really underdeveloped and easily attacked.  It's not about some authoritarian ruling on what people do/don't have the *right* to do; it's about what sort of society you want to live in.  Obesity has been (through scientific study) linked to all sorts of negative effects that, at best, you could paint as a trade-off for whatever a person might perceive as a benefit of being obese.  It really is pretty trivial to paint an argument against the normalization of being fat, and so attacking only people who are motivated by malice is a pretty poor defense of the idea of 'fat acceptance'.  What you see other people doing influences your own decisions about what sort of behavior is and isn't okay, even when you aren't informed enough to understand all of the consequences or options, and as you point out in your own video, becoming a healthy weight after you're already fat is a difficult task.   By attacking people for attacking the normalization of being overweight, you're exacerbating the problem, which you can really only defend if you want to fully throw up your hands and say that society isn't your problem, which would be directly contradictory to basically every other video on this channel.  Given, this video is pretty old at this point, so this is more left here for posterity; it's for all of the future viewers of the video more than anything.  Bottom line is I don't think you did a great job with this one.

calories in, calories out does work -- it's just not possible for everyone to conform to that kind of diet, especially if they're in a food desert or dependent on SNAP. it's also extremely difficult to permanently change your lifestyle and food habits, and crash dieting is a result of people wanting an impermanent quick fix that won't actually work. it's also self-defeating to say that most obese people never succeed in permanent weight loss, because EVERYONE can stay at a healthy weight, it just takes some people a lot more effort than others. a lot of people get discouraged and give up, which is why it's uncommon to succeed.

I'm REALLY concerned about the obesity rate in the US and I hate fat-shaming. People who do it just want to bully people and they pretend they have a 'good' reason for doing so. Personal responsibility is important and all, but when the obesity/overweight rate is as high as it is, it means that there are deeper, systematic reasons for it. And if you legitimately care about the collective health of the population, you'd focus on finding those reasons and figuring out solutions.

I'm glad you made this video. I think I have finally found a video of yours that doesn't change my perspective. Don't get me wrong, you're totally correct about these bullies, but I don't follow their ideology.  Maybe I'm a bad person, but my distaste for fat people isn't for their health. I find, probably confirmed by my bias, that often being fat is a symptom of poor discipline and behaviour patterns. Patterns that come through the personality as whole. Maybe not on a casual social level, but more probably if you live with them, or are related to them for example.  I find fat people to be largely unmotivated, more focused on instant gratification, quick to give up in the face of difficulty, and quick to justify their own poor foresight as a personal attack.  While most humans are like this, I find fat people to present this behaviour more, not just in diet, but with money, and other areas of their lifestyle. Making them more difficult roommates than someone who has the discipline to exercise, clean up after themselves, and delay gratification by saving, or not being indebted in anyway.  But that's just my anecdotal experience with a larger than average, but still relatively small sample size.  So I'm going to go ahead and assume that obesity is a symptom of personality flaws, so I will appropriately lower my expectations of your social capacity to maintain a harmonious environment.

I actually unsubscribed from Blair and ShoeonHead after they both decided to give their opinions and make videos about Fat acceptance and Thin Privilege.   I started gaining weight in fourth grade.  Trips to doctors didn't help.  Riding the bus was a nightmare.  I walked everywhere.  Basketball to try and help.  In high school it was even more.  Weights class 2-3 times a week, walking everywhere, marching band.  I found that eating 'diet like' foods at school would actually get me more bullying. (I started dieting in fourth grade.) Eventually via trial and error I found that eating lunch at school that was neither the worst option (pizza, burger etc.  ) or the 'best' option (salad) was my go to.  A milk, a chicken sandwich and a bag of fries.  I took my not eating to home.  After high school I got more intense.  I worked jobs that needed lots of exercise and moving around and went to the gym 5 hours a week.  I gained 10 pounds. . my breasts got smaller.  Nothing else changed.  I tried out for Biggest Loser 3 times.  They could fix anyone right?  Never got in.  I got married to a man that said prayer and more God would solve it.  9 years later and 1 divorce later I started seeing a new doctor.  A fat disorder doctor.  I have Stage III Lipedema.  Obesity is in my family.  My Uncle died from Gastric Bypass.  From complications that aren't advertised by doctors or insurance readily. (Gastric Bypass and GERD causing Esophageal Cancer) Losing weight just. . isn't in my future and never will be unless I can get insurance to pay for surgeries.   I tell you all of this because you are one of the few Fat acceptance videos I have ever seen that has actually talked about what Fat Shaming actually does.  Thank you.  You don't know how important it is for me to see someone that I admire and think the world of actually say things that don't hurt me.

For those that don't know Tess is a body positive activist and model. She is about 200 pounds over her frame making her morbidly obese. The issue her is I've read some of the comments in her videos of people saying they want to stay big because they have never been happier. Of course we should never bully these individuals, but we need to stand on a viewpoint where we all need to acknowledge this is neither healthy nor safe.  We have already done that with smoking. It's clear about the health effects of smoking. That's why no one is glamorizing it. If obesity is the second leading cause of preventable after smoking why are we all the sudden encouraging.  Of course I'm not saying you should be yelling at random overweight people on street(you weirdo), or laughing at them in YouTube videos, you just need to have an understanding that what they are doing is not good for them and it will ruin their joints and possibly shorten their lifespan. America's diet culture is really quite toxic. I've always had a normal, healthy weight (perhaps slightly curvy for an Asian girl - smaller waist and bigger boobs and hips). Back in China, other than thinking that I'm a bit bigger than the girls around me (but I'm also quite athletic), I never perceived myself as fat. Then, ironically, I moved to the US for grad school, where the average BMI is higher than China, and developed an eating disorder. I started having unrealistic expectations for an 'ideal' body type (and that's the real trick, isn't it - that all the healthy life gurus are telling you that you CAN achieve that body and that it's all about your personal effort - plus buying their PT guides/consultations). On top of an already busy and stressful schedule, I tried to fit in as many workout sessions as possible. When I failed to achieve them, I resorted to eating, which made me feel worse. I became bulimic although from the outside, I seemed normal and perhaps healthier/more active than average. I was experiencing shame that even my uber-critical Chinese parents couldn't have made me feel. And that's when I realized how warped the diet culture is in the US. I actually moved here from a slimmer country (statistically speaking), as a perfectly healthy person, and started to hate my body due to the pervasive influence of mass media, which I didn't even expose myself to that much. And that's why I think that body positivity is important.

'Maybe all critique can do is help you sketch the bars of your own prison...' The honesty, compassion, and humanity really doesn't succumb to the self-deprecating attempts to hide it. Love you so much, Contrapoints

This is a great video, the only problem I have is to tell obese people who lost weight that it's nearly impossible for them to keep it off. I think it takes a lot of work dedication and discipline, but some of us have kept our weight off for a while and we would appreciate people who would be our allies not to tell us, that in the end we'll never make it.  I know there are studies, that back up that point, but there are also many examples of people who have kept the weight off long-term, I'm talking many years. Maybe I will include a study later if I can find one, 'officially'. But I have known quite a few in my life and I intend to be one of them.  people focusing on negative Studies, who are just starting their journey, May find it discouraging. they may think 'if I'm destined to be fat anyway then why bother being healthy?' And while I may be still heavier than some of my peers, I have gotten a huge health benefit from losing weight, look way better and toned, and may want to add, that instead of telling people it's impossible to keep it off, it may be more accurate, to say that you have to be very incremental.  You should NOT be losing 40 pounds in four months (unless you're morbidly obese)  Someone like me, who lost 40 pounds in three years, might be better off because my body has gotten used to a certain size. I agree with you on most other topics but not this one. I'm certainly not in favor of fat shaming or bullying, and you're quite right to slam the vile behavior of these 'tough love' self-proclaimed fat-shamers. However, the idea of rebranding obesity as a 'celebration of excess', while well-meaning, is not much better. I certainly wouldn't take that stance about any other lifestyle choices that are actively harmful and I suspect you wouldn't either. Would you celebrate your friend's gambling addiction? Drug abuse? Self-harm? I think not.   The idea that for many people it's impossible to lose weight even if they try is wrong and harmful in almost all cases (the exceptions being crippling disabilities and some rare diseases). That's very similar to the self-perpetuating philosophy of incels you talk about in another video: it's a comforting falsehood that causes people to wallow in their problems instead of taking steps to improve their situation. And as much as I sympathize with that, I cannot support or encourage that kind of self-destructive behavior.   If you want to argue that not everyone has to be healthy, that's fine by me. I'm not going to tell any fat person that they have an obligation to eat less or exercise more, that's their decision (at least until global warming causes food shortages and it's no longer morally defensible to eat more than you need, but that's another story). But that decision to remain overweight should be taken consciously, with the knowledge that there is a genuine alternative.    I'm not saying that everyone can have a model's figure, and I agree that society sets unfair standards. Chasing perfection is not the answer either. However I firmly believe that the vast majority of people can achieve a reasonably healthy weight, if they want it.

I read a paper by some psychologists (I don't remember the title or authors) that were arguing that race is a biologically meaningless construct, and in one segment they said something along the lines of (and this is not a direct quote) 'tendency to obesity is as genetically determined as skin color, therefore it would literally make as much sense to divide people into 'curvy' and 'lanky' as to divide them by skin color. Obviously, both are nonsense on a biological level.'    It was meant as a critique of race, but honestly, doesn't it work as a critique of our attitudes about body type? A significant percentage of any given population are born with more adipose cells and therefore the tendency to weigh more, have a thicker body type and have more difficulty losing weight. Is it not a type of racism, then, to marginalize people based (potentially) on unchangeable, hereditary facts of their biology? Obviously there was never slavery or Jim Crow for overweight people, but there is unnecessary discrimination against them, so can we not make a case that this is a form of mild racism?

There's nothing wrong with wanting to be thin. Why do you play at that being a bad thing at the end? Consciousness is the important part. We don't fix society by over-correcting our harmful behaviors until there's an equal amount of two different kinds of harm. Two wrongs don't make a right - that's fixing problems 101 material.

Obesity comes from childhood trauma as well.  The fat serves as emotional/physical protection.  It can feel like a warm hug if the child had been neglected sweetness and love from the parents.  They find the sweetness in foods instead.  Perhaps the reason why weight is so hard to loose is because there are deeply buried emotional issues that don't let them loose weight.  They would have to totally change the way they cope with everyday life and painful memories.  Or they would have to drastically change their lives in order to make it so that there is less suffering they have to cope with.  I wholeheartedly believe many people with medical issues would benefit from seeing a good therapist before doing any surgeries.   The idea that shaming works is so stupid.  If emotional or physical pain, through the form of shaming and punishment is what caused people to become obese as a coping mechanism, shaming them would just make them put on more weight as a way to cope and protect themselves.   In order to help someone you have to extend understanding and compassion to them.  You have to enter into their perspective.  You shouldn't hypothesize what you would do if you were them.  You should try to imagine what it is like being them as them.  Removing all your childhood experiences and becoming curious about what they might have experienced, and filling in the gaps with your imagination.  It's basic empathy, imagining what its like to be another person. Right wing people must have really low IQs because emotional understanding is like the easiest thing out of all the mental capacities a human has.  They are assholes, so disconnected from their own emotions and their own suffering, that they can't relate to anyone else. I know retribution would be sinking down to their level but I sometimes imagine if they are met with an awful event in their life, they will some how have no other choice but to come face to face with their suffering and finally get it.  They will finally have to break down, let their life fall apart and grieve.

I know this is an old video, but I just want to chime in because I used to be 425 pounds. I'm currently 292 and continuing on my way down. It's been a long journey with a lot of ups and downs. Some months I lost 10 pounds, others I lost only 3, then back to 10. Honestly, one of the biggest things that helps with something like weight loss is having a supportive network of friends and family. When you have nothing at all and food is the only thing that can provide you a bit of comfort even if you know you are killing yourself, you may just decide to eat more. I have friends and family who want me to be well and I want to be well, and I want to live the longest, happiest, and healthiest life I can - and this is what has kept me on the right track for the last nearly two years.   Now let me get one thing straight - I want to be the healthiest me regardless of what anyone says. If people have a problem with me, I can shrug it off - but not everyone is in the same position as I am and they won't all react to stressors like bullying in the same way that I will. As contra mentioned in the video, it often just makes people worse off. When a lot of people bully you about something and make you feel worthless and miserable, you retreat to the habits that you know are bad for you but provide you at least some comfort... I think the message of fat acceptance is very irresponsible but at the same time the solution to the problem it somehow tries to alleviate obviously isn't to bully people. I think there is some idea in consciously assessing the culture we build around being overweight, if you want the people of tomorrow to not suffer excess misery from obesity you'd probably want to try to fix the epidemic itself but also to keep the condition as socially neutral like any other disease so that you don't hurt people too much in the process. I think the goal would be to build something where obesity doesn't spread, but something that also doesn't make people who are fat any more miserable. The idea of 'health' is itself debatable of course but one thing is sure, being overweight increases your risk of almost any possible disease (weakened immune system and overworked organs make your response to viral threat, strain, etc. considerably weaker), early mortality and probably even most importantly worse quality of life. Being obese or heavily overweight is a disability and debilitates you in all physical activity to some extent. Also the obvious markers of worsened quality of life are the somewhat increased likelihoods of different mental illnesses like depression, but even most obvious of all are the self-reports of obese people, especially those who have since lost the weight. I am one of those people and I can say that being overweight was way more debilitating than many would think, fat tissue is an active organ that effects your hormone production, especially when it comes to eating and mood. It's at least a vicious cycle where you get hungry faster and don't feel full when you should as you eat since insulin disrupts your leptin production and function. I'll put it bluntly, you feel like shit all the time and if you've been fat since you were a kid you probably think that it's normal to feel that way. When I lost my first significant amount of weight I felt like superman. Also it's an almost impossible mental gauntlet to feel crushing personal failure every single time you come across some stairs and know that it's your problem that you're paying for in those instances. Nobody forcibly made you fat even if you want to shift the blame to someone else, your environment makes a difference but at the same time it is your personal vessel so after a certain age it becomes your problem no matter how it started. I wouldn't want it for my worst enemies.  What does it mean to be overweight has fluctuated over the years from positively symbolizing wealth to negatively symbolizing greed to now symbolizing or being evidence of sloth and gluttony.  I don't think the solution is to throw in the towel and begin accepting it as a new norm, our children and their children are the ones that'd get screwed over with that, culture matters since it's the legacy we leave to those we care about the most. I think it is very similar to if the opioid epidemic got even more out of hand, and addicts being large enough portion of the population, we'd start opioid drug addiction acceptance or we'd at least shift the condition to something of a neutral character trait and not a value judgement or a condition to treat. It's ok that the most likely cause of death for an American is a drug overdose because everyone does it, it's almost unavoidable since the drugs are everywhere and they're addicting, of course it's normal since chasing highs is human nature #SICC  Sure that would be a coping strategy but it doesn't promote solving the ultimate problem and it doesn't take into account that there will be loads of generations of people after us and this is not a direction you'd want to lead them if you had any sense.  There is no doubt a social element to the condition so I deem it very unwise and irresponsible to move goalposts towards excess weight being something to celebrate, I think among adults it could be good to see the fatness issue as a matter of personal responsibility, so who cares if you're fat as long as you don't make your kids fat, but I think actual intentional campaigning or a 'movement' that shifts the wider culture around it is just plain social degradation and self-centered egoism. Culture is what we give to children so that they don't have to start building morals and knowledge independently from the ground up, not seriously warning them about proven bad habits and negative coping strategies is an idiotic idea, when they finally learn it'll be too late for them since health affects you from day one. Childhood obesity is a heavy negative predictor of overall lifetime success and at that point it is not personal choice, it's beyond vile to even take the risk of raising its prevalence without a seriously good reason for doing so and I don't think the blind professed empathy in the name of hypothetical social justice is good enough. I used to be over 300 lbs and I've kept myself in the 170 range for 5 years now by body fat percentage is currently at around 16% where it used to be 35%. I'm not a superhuman mutant who achieved an impossible feat but this discussion is very much my wheelhouse.   I would have lost the weight sooner but hearing this 'obese in remission' 'it's just going to come back' bullshit really had me feeling hopeless for a long time. It's hogwash, a myth, those stats have largely been disproven, and promoting that sort of fatalist incel sui-fuel is blatantly irresponsible. Your body reflects your lifestyle and when you make sustainable lifestyle changes... you actually sustain the changes reflected in your body. These studies proving 'obesity in remission' generally focused on crash dieters, biggest loser-type weight loss, lipo, gastric bypass, cool sculpting, and other quick fixes. However the way people talk about it promotes this ridiculous idea that fatness is genetic or inescapable (it's not).   I also learned, growing up in a hyper polite culture enabling my slow suicide, that compliments paid by others were bullshit, and I could only ever trust the bully in my head. I think THAT is where real mental health concerns and body dysmorphia comes in, I can tell other people to fuck off but not really my second self. Like I really was killing myself and everyone who 'loved' me was smiling along while I was doing it. That's some seriously deep cruelty if you really think about it.  I think it's very important to talk about the causes of obesity, and it really is a complicated conversation. Like on one hand capitalism promotes shitty food and our over worked schedules don't leave much room, but at the same time I'm a poor person I can tell you right now that a healthy diet is a lot cheaper than daily takeout (which we are seeing a lot of) and a quick google search brings up millions of healthy budget friendly 5 minute recipes so I don't really see 'society' as being the answer. When obese people walked past, they were, almost inevitably, Americans. Here in Europe, we have national health services. The problem is that there is more and more discussion about spending obesity, which means that resources that should be channelled into fighting real diseases are used to help people who are fat.

Underlying this fat-shaming business is the notion that a woman's only value or primary value is in her looks.  Thus, Jenny McCarthy is an anti-vaccine nut who should be shunned out of the public sphere because her stupidity is a threat to children, but people still want to know what she thinks because she is considered conventionally good-looking.  But on the other hand, a woman could be recognized for an important contribution to humanity through, say, a Nobel prize, and people all over the world will respond to the announcement of her prize with 'Yeah, but is she good-looking?'  This causes fat-shaming to do a lot more damage than it should.  I'm a fat man and it's obvious that fat-shaming hurts me a lot less than it does fat women.  I don't know that we spend enough time talking about how these various cultural assumptions twist and distort and generally fuck things up. I'm a heterosexual man and I enjoy looking at women, but a woman's looks should not be the most important thing (much less the only important thing) about a person.

Fat hate is a battleground over the existence of free will. I've often wondered about why I instinctively feel prejudiced against people who are very overweight, and my conclusion is that I am somewhat threatened by them. We know that fat people do not want to be fat, and we also know that on a purely physical level, they have the ability to stop being fat (a person who simply stops eating entirely will lose weight fairly quickly, we can be sure of that). But, generally speaking, they continue to remain overweight. This presents a philosophical dilemma. I want to believe that people have the ability to make choices, and have the ability to act rationally and logically despite discomfort. The simple existence of overweight people is a visual, human reminder that for at least some people, that simply isn't true. And the same thinking that says 'if they can do it, I can do it too!' leads me to to the unnerving 'if they can't do it, perhaps I couldn't either'. As a person with a lifetime of good eating habits for which I must thank my upbringing, a low appetite, and naturally tall (thus increasing my need for calories) - it is easy to project these insecurities on a group whose problems I can't identify with.    I think there is a desire to 'do something', and I think most people who are 'fat haters' ultimately agree on this deep down - I don't care about fat people, really (perhaps individuals, but not the group). I simply would prefer there to be less fat people. This kind of self centred thinking does not take the individuals concerned into account, and leads easily to shaming - which, ironically, doesn't seem to be effective - but is easy and feels good. The shaming leads naturally from the desire to believe in free will and control - I want to believe I perfectly control my body and actions. They must also be able to control their body and actions. They do something that harms themselves? The psychologically easiest conclusion is they are simply weak or stupid, and thus contemptible. Thus I can protect my feelings and ideals at the expense of compassion. This is a trade most people are willing to make.

Difficult subject for me. I definitely agree that shaming and bullying are wrong. I also agree that it's important to provide role models that empower kids to be whoever they want to be, and live their lives free of stigma and shame. But this is where things get difficult for me: Where is the line between body-positivity + encouraging freedom of choice, and promoting unhealthy choices? I mean, there's a reason why nobody is calling for role-models advocating anorexia, smoking, alcoholism, drug abuse etc. Apart from this issue, the other problem I have is not wanting to shame or bully people + wanting to respect their freedom of choice vs. standing by watching someone eat or smoke or drink themselves into mental or physical ill-being. In such situations, I see no way to bring up my concerns without making that person feel ashamed or offended to some degree, even if that is not my intent. When I don't say anything, I carry around a feeling of guilt and regret for not speaking up. So idk, it's kind of a lose lose situation here, and my moral compass is spinning, no resolve in sight.  Anyways, I wanted to say thanks for your brilliant content and the work you put into debating contrapoints. Discovered your channel 2 days ago and been binging your vids since. The thing about obesity is that a lot of morbidly obese patients have an unhealthy relationship with food. Watch 'My 600 lb Life' and you'll find that almost all of them used food to make themselves feel better (the real tragic ones because of sexual violence from their childhood) and fat shaming only drives them to eat *more* food. Too recover from morbid obesity one has to do more than stop eating--they have to learn how to find happiness away from food and how to accept themselves. So first off I am not trying to tell anyone what to do but if you do want to lose weight this is good advice. There are a lot of false solutions out there. Everyone likes to focus on dieting and cardio but these don't really help because the weight will come right back after you stop. What does work is weight training and cutting sugar. Cutting soda and alcohol(if you prefer to drink alcohol then you will probably have to cut grains) out of your diet and doing 3 10 minute kettlebell routines a week is all most people really need to do. You want to do exercises that build muscle to increase your resting metabolism so you can lose weight with minimal dietary changes. Drinking black coffee(has to be black. Milk slows down the caffeine intake diminishing the hunger reducing effect and sugar is counter productive. You will get used to the taste pretty quickly. buy good medium or light roast coffee) instead of eating breakfast also helps because breakfast is actually a fairly recent addition for non rich people(as the photos above show, those rich people were pretty heavy). Anyways the real problem with obesity is it is very easy to get to a point where you cannot do things like kettlebell routines and I hate to say it but one persons poor health is a burden on everyones insurance premiums. It is a good idea for the sake of health to keep track of your weight and adjust behavior if you see it increasing. As stated in the video it is much easier to gain than to lose. Anyways these are the things I did when I started becoming overweight. I still eat whatever I want. I do allow myself to be hungry from time to time. I also cook my own meals. Standing in front of a stove burns a bit of calories too plus I can control how much fat and sugar is in my meal. That said I use tons of butter.  A lot of people like putting off these changes but what it really comes down to is do you want to be, insert characteristic or addiction here, the rest of your life. If the answer is no there is no better time to start than today. This goes for addictions as well which also tend to be shamed. Basically do what you want but if you see something that you have control over, addiction, weight, ect., as a problem, do not put off taking action because it will only get harder as you get older.  Anyways again not trying to shame or tell people how to live their life. Just sharing what worked for me to those who do want to lose weight.

Summary: This comment is a combo of ass-kissing agreement with one possible disagreement/critique about celebrating fatness. Yes my YouTube comments are too long.  Not good at this format.  Too lazy to change.    I absolutely love your channel.  I agree with you more than 90% of the time mostly because you don't get caught up in the fallacies that derail too many people - namely reductionism, dichotomization and ignoring context. Those kinds of biases/fallacies often lead to absurd and extreme ideological positions from fascism to less dangerous but annoying and counterproductive out-of-touch self-righteous absurdist identity politics (as opposed to valid reasonable ID politics).    But at the end were you suggesting we celebrate fatness and obesity?   I appreciate you being conscious of conflating overweight with morbid obesity.  However, the science is overwhelming clear that overweight is also unhealthy. I also appreciate not conflating health with morality and being pragmatic in noting shame doesn't work so well (even if someone thought it morally ok).   But it seems like a kind of dichotomization or contrarianism to suggest that if shaming is bad (I agree) that celebration and encouragement of ill-health (albeit just one scientifically confirmed aspect of ill-health) is good.    On the other hand, you could argue that celebration of fatness could undo the harm of shame.  But that is also dichotomization.   We can certainly find a middle ground can we not?     I say all this as someone who used to be in public health, recognizing that health should not be conflated with morality and also being able to keep health in perspective (eg we don't need to do everything perfectly from a health standpoint). But overweight/obesity and its consequences are pretty staggering and mind blowing at individual and societal levels.    Like I said, I rarely find the opportunity to disagree (because you are awesome) and you do invite comments of disagreement.  Ok let's face it, I'm writing this for me more than you. I was a philosophy major (with grad degrees in social work and public health) and love to discuss, debate etc. I realize I am probably amplifying your suggestion(?) of fat celebration for this purpose.    I don't mean to blow smoke up your skirt but your channel is a breath of fresh air.  Thanks for the content.  Maybe someday I can be a patron.

I've been watching a lot of your videos and I agree much more than I expected on various things, in some other things I disagree. But in this one there is something that really ticks me off. You say it's none of your business to tell other people they should be healthy and you don't think its virtuous to be healthy, but a sick person can't be a functioning member of society. Obesity is a huge burden on healthcare systems because it comes with a plethora of other life-threatening, long lasting diseases like hypertension, diabetes and heart disease. If the United States ever wants to dream about universal healthcare then you can't have the attitude of 'I'm not going to say anything about other people's unhealthy habits, its none of my business'. Some of the fundamental pillars of public health are education and community involvement. While telling an obese person 'stop eating you're unhealthy' isn't going to do shit, saying 'lets just accept diverse body types' will not bring any real solution to the problem and in fact, its going to make it worse.

I think you have put it brilliantly. While I agree with most of the points you have mentioned, there is one point that I don't think you have effectively talked about. Being skinny does not necessarily mean one has good health. There are a lot of things that can be wrong with one's health even if they are skinny, and some of those things might actually have caused the person to be skinny. But being obese almost always comes with health risks. You say it's not necessarily a virtue to have good health, and I agree with that. But I would rarely shy away from telling a friend or family that they would benefit from losing a few pounds if it seems so.  Because obesity is linked to appearance, and given the body-shape standards the media has promoted, it is a sensitive issue. And the more sensitive an issue is, the more bullies we see exploiting it. I don't think the solution is to stop talking about it, but to have more informed and sympathetic conversations. Also the focus needs to move away from appearance to health. Bullies like Milo use the 'health' card to really go after one's appearance.

Obesity isn't just anyone's individual fault, but it IS possible for any individual to overcome it. There's a massive pseudo science nutrition info that spreads every few years. They're all just the atkin's / keto diet over and over again, and there's no credible evidence to prove it's healthy. We know what foods will NOT make us obese, and that's what we need to teach people to eat. Honestly, giving people the power of knowledge over their own plates will make a BIG difference.

Speaking as a former obese person, overcoming the shame and humility is hard, and an ongoing process. That being said, It took me less than a year to lose 60 lbs by commiting to the gym, at my own pace, multiple times a week, and giving myself only healthy options for food, save the **ACTUAL** occasional treat. Diet is the main factor here. I let myself eat as much food as I pleased, and all foods that I love. But I only ate foods I knew were proven to be good for my health, with no negative health consequences, and have been proven to lower CVD risk, cancer risk, and diabetes risk. I ate **PLANTS**.  Really, I'm not bullshitting; Kids, eat your damn veggies. #GoVegan #WholeFoodsPlantBased

The general population does not know how to be within a respectable BMI. All you need to do, really, is to: consume no sugar, avoid artificial sweeteners, workout for about 30 minutes daily, don't down two pints of beer after every work shift and practice meditation (in whatever form that suits you).   Unlike what many think, calories in and calories out is a big meme, partially. It is not just a matter of how much you eat, it is also how this food is used by the body. Now you may cry 'that's genetics!!!!' and while this is partly true, you have more control over this than the DNA strands inside your puny cells. There is a fantastic hormone known as insulin. This beauty, in part, regulates you sugar levels in the blood but also how food is utilized by your body. Without getting into too many details, if you can decrease your insulin resistance, you can also ensure that your body does not convert too much of the calories consumed into reserve for later. Commonly called fat. So how does this insulin resistance increase or decrease? Simple, insulin is a reaction to what you eat and if you stop eating the foods that increase it very highly (the ones mentioned above) or, what leads me to my next great tool against obesity, fasting.   Fasting will not kill you. You are not meant to eat 3 meals a day, that is a complete scam by the food industry. You can survive for extremely long on just water and a few minerals such as salt and potassium. An obese man weighing 400lbs didn't eat for 280 days and he lived without ever going back above 200lbs. I did not eat for two weeks during my final week of exams and did just fine. Fasting is even used to treat type 2 diabetes. Now that this myth is out of the way: why fasting? Fasting means that you don't eat anything except water and a few gellules with your salt and potassium in it. If you don't eat anything then your body will have to search for food and unlike what you think, it won't eat your muscles. Picture a caveman; he is hungry. Food has run out two days ago and he needs to find a source of food. Luckily, his body isn't completely dense and actually used the storage of energy (fat) that it has. Caveman finds a source of food the day after. He lost 3 lbs but three pounds of fat, not muscle. That would be stupid. Muscles take more energy to produce than fat and have significantly less energy. So although this is a fictional story about a caveman, this is still a mechanism that other animals, including humans, have. Camels store fat on their back to be used when food is scarce. Now, you don't eat calories, you lose fat. Simple but there's even more to it. Your insulin resistance decreases and your addiction to sugar is better. Oh by the way, you don't feel hungry when you fast for a few days.  Finally, sugar. Sugar is a highly addictive drug that is being put into your food everyday from dusk to dawn. Fat was initially scapegoated as the cause for obesity when in actuality it is sugar. If sugar is a drug then why is it allowed? Multi-billion industry is my answer for you. It makes people addicted and paired with the fact that eating feels almost half as good as an orgasm for the brain, it is quite easy to understand why people are paid to shut up about the issue. This is not the case so much today but my brother still insists that fat makes you fat and so this leads me to believe that others may think this as well. I previously mentioned 'your sugar addiction is better' and by this I mean that you will not have intense cravings for sugar as you did prior to a fast. Of course, this is not going to last forever as you can get hooked on sugar again but it is an easy fix.   I will conclude this monstrous blog post here and if you actually managed to read through my unedited shitpost and want to learn more, the key words are: water fasting, jason fung and why sugar is bad.

The whole 'tough love' falls apart when you know that a lot of disordered eating stems from traumatic events.  For example, a large number of women develop binge eating disorders after being raped.  An anecdote:   A member of my eating disorder support group started binge eating as a teenager after being raped.  She wanted to put on weight because she didn't trust men that hit on her.  She grew up, met a man that loved her for who she is, had children who she adores and comfortably lost some weight.  That took ~20 years.  Now in her 40s living a comfortable life, she gets raped again.  The sense of control from exercise and fasting became her addiction as a coping mechanism.  She now suffers from anorexia nervosa.  Her life is in danger, she knows it, she knows what she can do but it is incredibly hard.  So hard that she instinctively rather risk dying and be hospitalized than have as much as late and NOT go to the gym for 3 hours a day.  The last thing she needs, as she's learning how to cope healthily with her trauma, is to be shamed in the media and by health professionals (yes, the later has happened).  She feels shame enough by herself already.

If one eats a healthy (not crazy neurotic healthy but general health) and exercises regularly then I'm cool with them being fat. Some people look good fat and they're fun to hug. Fat is an important part of our body (brain, joints, organs, warmth, etc).   My main reasoning behind being healthy is for proper neurotransmitter production and secretion. Along with the psyche that freedom of health brings (can do most any physical thing one wants).   As far as the lingering anxiety, we want to be thin and attractive so we can attract sexual partners as well as obtain the power that comes along with desire. These are instinctual cues from 'Darwinian theory' and also signifiers that we managed to overcome a common hardship in life (healthy in modern times).   When it comes to fat shaming, compassion is needed. Most overweight people are uneducated or have mental health issues (being as small as a lack of self-efficacy or/and discipline). Shaming them is one method but it is far less effective then authentically and compassionately delivering the truth.  I don't recommend we pretend that being obese is fine or that we make fat sexy. Going about acceptance and promoting healthy change in a compassionate and loving manner is a much more effective route though. I've been bullied for being fat since I first started school and now I think I have an eating disorder, but I don't really know. I'm in grade 9. At first it was just a diet for me to do for a month or so, but I've been watching what I eat and exercising excessively for a whole year. All I think about is food and what I'll weigh the next time I step on the scale.

I'm against fat acceptance. However, I do also not advocate going around telling people 'uwu you're fat and should seek help',' hahah no you're just lazy'. You know what? Maybe some people really are. But that's still no reason to go out of your way to pretend to 'care' for someone's health. Being overweight really does not feel good. Not in a 'body image' and 'self esteem' perspective, but from the actual ORGAN and GUT feeling. Who enjoys feeling bloated and cold? Who enjoys having little stamina? And while no one should grab these 'arguments' right out of the context and go 'hahah, see? People agree with my stupid excuse for bullying innocent people', I cannot exactly say that I 'promote' the (at least in my eyes) 'glorification' of being at a weight limit by PERSONAL CHOICE that will impact your cardiovascular health and your well-being overall. Most of the people who are being told, or hell, are even telling themselves, that they're 'fat' are actually so slight over the apparently norm-accepted weight that a little exercise of choice will do the trick. I will not be able to tell if they'll be happier after, but again; It's a choice thing. But bullying will lead to mental health problems which can last up to a lifetime. And which is easier to talk about and to fix? A body that has just those few kilos more or a mind that can't love itself anymore?

I don't think fat shaming/ bullying is ok at all, but 'healthy at every size' and 'every bodytype is beautiful' is where i draw the line. I completely agree with the points you brought up against clowns like Milo. They really do seem to just want to bully people, and concerns about health are just their way of trying to justify their behavior. In the end, their methods are counterproductive at best and outright destructive at worst.  Though, I disagree with the notion that society should 'give up' on trying to combat the obesity problem. It's a very complex issue and will be difficult to solve, but just because something is hard doesn't mean it's not worth trying to fix. You mention that 'someone else being fat doesn't effect me,' but especially if the given society wants something like universal healthcare, it does. In the long-term, it means more money spent on fixing the health problems an obese population is more prone to getting.  Even in the more abstract, the issues that lead to my neighbor being fat can lead to me being fat, be it lack of healthy food available, lack of education on nutrition, increased stress in the jobs available, etc. Being obese is not healthy and has many causes, and also societal effects.We shouldn't 'just move on' from a public health crisis. I also see some people pointing out 'Well, in the past, being fat was actually an attractive thing.' I find that to be such a silly point to make. People in the past didn't know any better, there was a period of time where doctors thought it was fine to deliver babies without washing their hands first. There were also times where royal families thought inbreeding was healthy because it 'kept the blood pure.' Why does it matter so much what some Roman society thought was attractive? We know now that obesity has long-term negative health effects.

I think something else to understand is that 'being fat' and 'being healthy' arent ALWAYS mutually exclusive concepts? Fat is just fat. Everyone has some fat on them, and some people have more or less fat on them than others. They're cells that hold onto extra energy that the body currently isn't using, something that used to help us survive throughout prehistory. That's it. Not to mention that, what a shocker, it's possible to have health problems from being too skinny too.   Can too much fat cause health problems? Yes. But having too little fat can do the same, and more often than not the 'social' standard for skinniness can have just as many health issues attached to them as fat people.   So maybe what we should do is frame the discussion less as 'how to loose weight to become skinny' and instead discuss it as 'what role does fat play in the overall complexity of the spectrum of human health and what can we do to improve it, regardless of body type.'

(also im gonna apologize beforehand for the fucking novel im about to type up down here, sorry) 1. is talking about fat people in a non-shaming way really promoting fatness? if so, that MUST mean showing a character on TV with a wheelchair in a positive light is promoting conditions that cause leg paralysis, right? there's a character with tuberculosis, which must mean that strange talking box is telling us all to go get tuberculosis! it's ridiculous. it's just a way to sugar-coat the fact that they don't want to even LOOK at an entire group of people. 2. even if #1 is false, there really... isn't a way to promote fatness like everyone is claiming. a LOT of people that end up obese usually end up that way no matter what their diet or lifestyle looks like, because when someone is predisposed to it their body will find a way to gain the weight and keep it on. take it from someone who's 5'5 and 170 lbs despite all the 800-calorie diets, the after-every-meal-purging, the flat tummy teas, the flat out fasting, and the obsession with putting my heart rate near 200 on the treadmill. this has been going on for years, and if being fat was a choice, i sure as hell wouldn't still be a size 12 given how i live. 3. there's some sort of deep-seated anxiety in the center of that statement, like what Contra touched on in the last portion of her video. TLDR; it's not about health, it's about being scared that accepting fatness means they themselves will become fat.

I don't know how much stock you put in personal anecdotes or how much truth you expect some random fuck on the internet to speak, but I feel the need to share and persuade anyway. A few years ago, I decided to actually get control of my life and my body, and so I began my journey of being healthy. In about a year's time went from 270lbs to 175, my squat went from an empty barbell to 250lbs. A lot of that was fueled by shame, anger, and a multitude of feelings I kept repressed for my entire life. But even with that, the crux of the whole thing was a desire to get better, and the discovery that the way of doing so is simple. You can't surrender yourself to the way things are. Despair is comforting, and it seems a lot easier to let yourself rot and endure your self-pity than it is to change your habits. I'm getting too poetic for a youtube comment. The point I'm trying to get to is that obesity, a disease, should not be celebrated. It can be cured and should be, it's empowering and liberating for the person suffering from it to be rid of it. The simple act of being fat is miserable and exhausting (I speak of the mere physicality of it, not the social stigma and the self worth issues that stem from that, body image and the development of dismorphia are a different can of worms). And I am certainly not advocating for the shaming of people suffering from the disease, they have enough personal demons screaming at them to make themselves miserable. The last thing they need are real monsters reinforcing those voices. I'm advocating for the education of health; that people should know how their bodies work, what to do with their bodies to keep it working well, and that keeping yourself from developing too much fat can take up as much of your daily routine as taking a daily bath (barring medical extremities).

If you really want to help people, talk about insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome instead of critiquing your mortal enemies. Otherwise this comes across as facetious. You simultaneously agree that the conditions that whatever causes: various and assorted food industries, stressors, income, what have you are causing super morbid obesity in the masses. But at the  same time you're talking about people have to accept those stressors and factors as some kind of fatalistic fact that can never be changed. No, no they do not have to be accepted as one's 'lot' and yes, yes they can most definitely be reversed.     I'm saying this as a former fat person who still is according to statistics slightly overweight and still has a little bit left to lose but it's a hell of a lot better now than when I was obese. I was prediabetic, and my health was at the worst it's ever been.   *And* I had no idea why my clothes were suddenly getting tighter even though I was eating on average one Pepperidge Farm coconut cake a week. I had a lot of stress going on in my life , a relative was dying of cancer,  I had been in not one but two abusive relationships concurrently: there was a lot of stuff.    So imagine my shock and horror when I go to a new doctor who very seriously tells me that I am obese. You could've knocked me over with a feather.   When I was told this, do you think I ran back to the coconut cake? Not on your life. I took it as seriously as the inevitable  heart attack and/or Hypertension I was no doubt looking forward to if I kept doing what I was doing. I reversed it through learning about nutrition, learning about what a calorie is, learning about obesity related disorders and how to reverse them. Learning about inflammation: learning about insulin resistance,  Learning about the fact that I was sensitive to gluten and grains and basically had to say goodbye to them permanently,  Learning about the ketogenic diet, learning learning learning about everything I could as if my life depended on it. And guess what? It did!   I reversed the pre-diabetes state I was in and I saved my health because I had to save my life. It was that important.   And I have a serious thyroid disease! You know, the excuse always used to make weight loss hard for people?  I didn't even work out. I just changed the way I viewed food. I educated myself on what foods worked for my body and I used it to its fullest advantage. I researched the heck out of the subject.    Some people need to be scared straight. I'm not suggesting fat shaming of course,  but we don't need to accept fat, either.  I don't need to embrace it as this 'cultural phenomenon'. It's a *health condition* and it's a *health epidemic* and it's a danger to that person's life! It is very serious. It's not a joke!   At end of the day most morbidly obese people do not understand what a carbohydrate is , what a protein is , and what healthy and unhealthy fats are and how they interact with their unique biology. Believe it or not it's not about portion control. It's not about counting calories. It's about understanding how carbohydrates fats and proteins interact with your body. And also understanding that basically refined sugars and preservatives and chemicals that are artificially injected in/sprayed on food also play a role.  Some people are more insulin resistant than others.  Some people are more prone to body inflammation than others. It could be argued that it is a number of those factors you mentioned.  If there's an obese or morbidly obese person who after researching all of the stuff and cognitively understands it still does what they're doing without activating some kind of pro health program for themselves, then they need a psychologist they don't need a nutritionist. There's something mentally wrong with that person's worldview if they choose to remain obese. As you stated no obese person would actually choose to be obese unless there was some kind of trauma or  early childhood trauma defense mechanism in place that went unresolved in which case I have nothing but compassion for that person not ridicule and I wish them wellness and I hope they heal their childhood wounds.     But  if we're being really honest , also show me a super morbidly obese person who hasn't done anything to improve their situation who knows exactly what any of those  terms are. At the end of the day it boils down to super morbid ( in some cases willful) ignorance.  And ignorance should not be accepted.

TW: eating disorders including side effects, suicide.    I really like your show but I find it really unfortunate that you included a 'joke' about bulimia in this video. Eating disorders including anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, binge eating disorder and OSFED are deadly and destroy lives. Binging and purging through vomiting can inculde the lovely side effects of stomach or esophagus rupture, low electrolytes with heart attack and/or tooth decay/loss. You can read about some of these here URL (warning for graphic pictures) This is in addition to the mental torture of self hatred, anxiety, exhaustion, guilt, shame, suicidal ideation etc that comes with an eating disorder. The inclusion in a video addressing the anxiety around the pressure to be thin which is a component of eating disorders is not very respectful and disregards the seriousness of mental illnesses. Anorexia nervosa has the highest death rate when compared to other mental illnesses with bulimia and other eating disorders having increased mortality not just form the physical effects but the high rate of suicide. One of the barriers to weight loss includes emotional eating and on the extreme end of the binge eating disorder which brings about the same pain as with other eating disorders. If you could cut out the joke in this video that would be really good as eating disorders are no joke.

Let's not strawman the people who argue against so-called 'body positivity', i.e. the social acceptance of obesity. Not all of them are vitriolic, moralistic assholes who would like nothing better than to make fat people's lives miserable. In fact, I know several of them who genuinely care about their fellow humans, and who do not want to live in a society where the fear of offending or stigmatizing can lead to people being unhealthy. These people genuinely view overly permissive social norms around weight as a failure of compassion, and they have a point.   The body positivity crowd also has some good points: fat shaming can be stigmatizing, and it encourages some people to harass obese people - this is definitely detrimental to the person's mental health, it might lead to eating disorders and self-hatred, it might lead people to want to give up altogether on living a healthy lifestyle. And even if shaming worked, if the end result was that overall there are less health issues in society (physical and mental) as a result of shaming, we might still not want to live in a society where some people are made worse off to make a larger number of people better off. It could also be seen as an overly paternalistic society. I'm less sympathetic to other reasons to oppose fat shaming, like the sort of cultural relativism that makes people dogmatically venerate tolerance above all other values (while tolerance is important, it is not the only value, nor the most important, in my opinion).   However, paternalism is not always a bad thing. We know for a fact that obesity is not healthy, and if 35% of people are now obese (compared to less than half of that 50 years ago), then we have a public health crisis on our hands, we don't simply accept this as the new normal of an 'acceptable' body weight - the facts of biology plus the fact that we care about people's well-being determine what is a body weight that we as a society should 'accept' as normal, not some arbitrary social fiat. We want to live in a society where people are as well-off as possible (which includes being healthy), but not overly paternalistic. Society should not enforce social norms in a way that leaves some (even many) people worse off than they otherwise would have been, but to say that we should adopt laissez-faire social norms that prevent anyone from being stigmatized but also lead to even more people being worse off - no, that's not the kind of society I want to live in, and I doubt it's the one you want to live in.

From my personal experience (nearly 5 years of a severe eating disorder), the only way to keep weight off in the long term is to develop some very detrimental habits around food and exercise. When you diet, your body intentionally lowers metabolism and raises appetite. In my case, it got so bad that I had to eat under 1,000 calories per day and exercise 60-90 minutes daily in order to maintain my 'healthy sized' body. I even gained weight on 1,200 calories.When I started eating normally again and went through recovery, I gained every single pound back within two months. I have a very healthy diet of mostly plant foods and enjoy biking, walking, and swimming regularly, but am now technically over weight. Some bodies are just genetically larger, and while diet and exercise does contribute to weight a little bit, it is in no way as important to weight as the media and society makes it out to be. While this is a good video on it's own, I don't understand your leap from 'no fat-shaming' to 'fat acceptance'. First you go on to say that obesity should be viewed as a social epidemic and cite studies to  support it: Mass obesity is to be seen as a result of free market capitalism, cultural norms, marketing, psychology and genetics. This implies that it is not natural, but rather forced upon us.  But then you do the exact opposite and characterize obesity as a conscious choice, that other individuals have no right to question. You also suggest that our standards of truth and beauty are culturally biased and should be questioned. That is true, in the context of individual obesity, but not in the context of epidemic obesity. Here you also fail to mention studies and instead appeal to individualism, disregarding the fact that obesity correlates with depression and unhappiness (which would lead one to believe, that our conscious choices are not always in our best interest).  So we have a deterministic, quasi socialist view of obesity as an inevitable evil under the system and an individualistic, post modern view of obesity as something, that's not inherently bad. The solution of 'fat acceptance' doesn't solve the problem of obesity, it just further justifies its existance in a capitalist society. But it can't solve it, because it can't prevent people from involuntarily becoming obese, nor does it help them escape obesity, if they chose to do so. It only helps a select few feel slightly better about themselves.   TL;DR: obesity can't both be the result of society and of individual choices. Fat acceptance just sweeps the problem under a rug (thereby helping the system perpetuate it)  Also, I feel like this inherent contradiction is what people mean, when they talk about post modern marxism.

I know about this lingering anxiety very well and I'm convinced, that sketching the bars of your prison *is* all you can do. We live in this world, we are not independent of it and thus, we are shaped by it, even in ways we don't like. However, I think there are two advantages of actually seeing the bars of your cell. 1. You won't blame the sunshine or the other inmates for not being able to jump out of the window because you know what keeps you imprisoned. Or, to put it more bluntly, you can let your new found knowledge inform your decisions, your actions. 2. By knowing, what is wrong and why it's wrong you might learn what needs changing and how to change it, so that at least future generations won't be trapped the way we are. Or, to use the prison-analogy: you are able to draw a house without barred windows.

Fat-shaming is gross and wrong, but the counter-argument should not be 'open ourselves up to the celebration of the diversity of body types.' Obesity increases your risk of cancer, heart disease, heart attacks, autoimmune disorders, and basically all things humans should try to avoid to live healthy and long lives. Why should we celebrate this? We don't have to shame anyone but don't ask me to celebrate someone else's objectively unhealthy choices. Is there a genetic component to obesity? Sometimes, yes, but that doesn't account for a majority of cases unless somehow you want to argue that Americans have a genetic disposition to being obese, which obviously isn't true. Is there a genetic component to addiction? Yes, sometimes. Why shouldn't we 'celebrate the diversity of' self-harming drug habits? Some people are genetically predisposed to addiction, and those addictions sometimes manifest into food addictions, and sometimes into substance addictions. Should we celebrate all groups of people who make objectively unhealthy choices whether it's in regards to food, drugs, or general behavior? I can't really imagine a good argument to support that. I also can't imagine a good argument to support fat-shaming. If you want to be fat, go ahead, overeat and don't exercise, but don't ask me to celebrate your poor choices.

I think the only legitimate point in any possible anti-fat position, is one I'm surprised you didn't touch on: societal burden.  Obesity and morbid obesity cause health problems and premature death (thus the morbid). Consequences (apart from death) include a broad range of things we all know, from heart attacks to cancer. Things that require treatment, that, in a socialised society, will be paid for by the larger community, in whole or in part, depending. I'm actually strongly in favour of socialism, so don't take that as a criticism of that. But not purely in an economical sense is this burden manifest. The time of doctors and the nurses, as well as the occupation of beds, are also factors. But it's a murky topic that, in my opinion, has no clear answer as of yet. Lots of things we do are dangerous to our health. Are we to condemn sport? Home improvement? Driving a car? Where do we draw the line? I don't know. We can't become ultra safe zombies, and not everyone can be thin (and it'd probably be boring if we were) but surely we have some duty to our fellow people to actively attempt to lessen the burden we each provide one another. Not beyond our capabilities (that's a pointlessly absurd request) but to our honest best. What does that look like? Again, I just don't know. But it's something I think we should talk about as a people. There's a conversation to be had there, for sure.

In a system with social healthcare, you do want the general population to keep itself healthy. Because you pay for them to get healed.  A society with a proper healthcare system should therefore inform and teach individuals about health and it should encourage the formation of healthy habits in children.

I don't feel wholly convinced by your arguments here; I don't feel like you really address some of the main criticisms of 'fat acceptance',- That people worry fat acceptance risks simply pushing the goalpost of what is considered healthy weight, and that modern research shows there isn't such a thing as being 'healthy fat'; yeah people shouldn't be bullied, but if we as a society grow comfortable with a certain standard of health doesn't that risk further perpetuating that standard? Certainly we must do more than stigmatize it to fix the problem, but it still seems proper for society to maintain that obesity *is* a problem.  You argue, 'who are we to say someone should live healthier, it isn't our life,' But I feel that ignores the very real fact that health problems for other people impact society as a whole; Not only do societal health problems increase healthcare costs for everyone else, but it also puts a greater burden on society by lowering peoples ability to work/labor, and risks causing those people additional medical problems (Such as obesity damaging joints and muscles) to the point that those people later require physical help from others to perform simple daily tasks; it might sound silly, but the human frame simply isn't built for perpetually carrying that much weight, years of it on end can do irreparable and debilitating damage.

I think obesity is more of a systemic issue than an individual one, in America at least. I don't think it's necessarily about fat acceptance or shaming, because being obese is objectively bad for one's health and we should want to avoid it as a society (and if someone WANTS to be fat so be it, but as you stated in the video, most obese people don't like being obese). I think it has to do with corporate entities using cheap products that hijack our brains' evolutionary desire for things that are high in fat, sugar, and sodium to prey upon the lower classes. Because if you look at it, most morbidly obese people are poor due to food deserts in inner cities (poor areas with no access to grocery stores with healthy options, mostly only convenience stores with processed pre-packaged foods) and fast food restaurants being largely cheaper than healthier options.   Of course we shouldn't shame individuals for being, that I agree with, but I think this video failed to examine America's system of systemic poverty among lower classes and the negative health effects that it brings. Also those who are poor have to work longer hours and have less free time to exercise. I don't have the statistic at hand, but I read somewhere that being impoverished in America has a hugely negative effect on life expectancy, largely because of the lack of available healthy foods and free-time to exercise.

While I don't necessarily like the fat acceptance movement, I definitely agree that those you mentioned are assholes. My main problem with the fat acceptance movement is that it's not about acceptance, but rather veneration. Instead of simply not being assholes to those who are fat, which I suspect most people aren't, there seems to be a move even by you towards the end of seeing fat as beautiful, at least in a way. While there is nothing wrong with seeing fat as beautiful it has 2 critical flaws. Generally, like you pointed out, we can't necessarily change what we see as beautiful, you still want to be thin just like so many other people. Generally people feel this way. I much prefer a solution that doesn't attempt to change what I don't believe we really can. However even if we can change how people view fatness, will that really fix the problem? We can't view every body type as being beautiful. If we decide fat is beautiful, aesthetically so, then it is like that we will see skinny as ugly or at the very least not as good, leaving skinny people in the reversed position.   Now this is just critique and complaint that can go on forever, but I do actually have somewhat of a suggestion for a solution. Rather than an attempt to mold society for people I think it would be better to give people the tools to deal with society. It's kinda the give me the serenity to accept what I cannot change kinda thing. We can learn together to accept being fat if that truly cannot be changed. It's difficult and probably not a perfect solution, but it's definitely a hell of a lot easier and more  likely to succeed than changing something as entrained in our Society as our sense of beauty do that even solved the problem.  To end congratulations on reading my stupid ideas do you got this far, and that's me to contra for being the only reasonable feminist I've found on YouTube and I've tried very very hard. YouTube and google work hard to keep you in your bubble, but hopefully I'll escape

I agree with all your points but the one about being not being virtuous. Being a supporter of universal healthcare having 70 percent of the nation being overweight or obese is not a good thing. There are many factors related to body weight but telling people who are overweight it's healthy to continue theor bad habits seems counter productive just like most people encourage smokers to quit smoking .

The second point about personal responsibility and what the cause is i think is radically unimportant. At the end of the day, even if you take the absolute worst case scenario, where all the major fast foods are addictive as hell, a prevalence of processed foods, etc etc, at the end of the day you have two options, you can scream into the void or you can struggle to make your life a healthier one. You aren't going to stop mass producers from offering unhealthy foods, aside from your market choices, so at the end of the day you DO have to take responsibility. Of course the best environment to do that is with a good family and/or friendly support network who encourage you to eat better and work out together, but either way, you choose what goes into your body at the end of the day. On the first point i agree, i've never met someone who lost weight and kept it off from people being cruel, as i said, having that support network is key i think. especially for long term changes. on your third point about it being my business, i can understand that in your american context, but here in australia we have a socialized health care system, something i am all for btw. However i do not think someone with a born liver disorder should receive treatment before an alcoholic (assuming it comes down to that, which it can do) nor would i want my taxes going to subsidizing the effects of some things which are life choices, such as smoking, drug abuse and of course, unhealthy eating. The argument can be made that if one were to grow up in an impoverished house hold these things would be harder to avoid and less of a personal choice, but most people here are middle/trade class where there is enough wealth to make it a personal choice. Of course i wouldn't deny that person my taxes, but it personally makes me resentful as much as i am ashamed of that personality fault in myself.  Finally, the idea that we shouldn't do all we can to keep encouraging people to live healthier, and as you yourself said, happier lives. Like it or not, obesity is now one of the biggest health killers in the western world, so many diseases and health risks stem from it. The idea that we should normalize it is an absolute travesty to me, and is no different to trying to normalize the idea of smoking or excessive drinking (the second of which is unfortunately common). As i said before i do not condone shaming and bullying, however being forceful and clear about what it can do to your body (being obese) is not bullying. When my mother tells me she is scared im going to die and that i need to do something, that is out of love, not bullying (i am overweight btw). Instead i think that sporting and active culture should be promoted but more important than anything; real commitment to making sure people understand completely that the healthiest diet is simply the non processed one, fresh fruit,  vegitables and low processed meat like beef, lamb, whole fish ect.

This video and its arguments are utterly confused and disconnected.  First, showing that fat-shaming is bad does not mean fat acceptance is good.  Second, you show that America's weight problem is caused by many things.  I agree - although it's mostly just the high carb, high sugar, processed foods.  If we agree that this weight problem is relatively new, and caused by our horrible food options, why on earth would you want us to just accept this new paradigm?!  We see people are eating unhealthfully to the point that they're getting massively overweight and dying at an early age, and your answer is that we should accept a wider array of body types?  Why don't we, I don't know, try and do something about the major factors that are pushing horrible food on us?  Maybe we shouldn't have billion dollar marketing campaigns that target children with sugary food?  No, no, let's embrace hedonism...  Which brings me to another important point.  The reason people can't lose or keep weight off is because they continue to eat high carb.  This is often because doctors tell people to eat high carb.  We should be changing the dietary guidelines, getting doctors up to speed on the effects of carbs, etc.  Saying, there's nothing we can do because people who ate high carb and continue to eat carbs can't lose weight is foolish.  And if you think low/no carb is just another fad diet, it really isn't.  Mankind has no need whatsoever for carbohydrates.  You will die if you don't eat fat or protein, but you can survive without carbs indefinitely.  Carbs cause insulin resistance, carbs and the insulin responses they induce prevent fat burning, carbs cause increased hunger, the volatility of relying the glucose to run your brain and body causes mind fog and horrible hunger pangs.  I could go on and on.  This serious problem of weight gain can be addressed through sensible application of science and logic.  Saying, we should just accept people's different sizes is totally ignoring the problem.
