I'd moved from a rural area where I could bike, rollerblade and explore to an exurb where I had the option of trying to bike/rollerblade on streets so badly maintained that cars had issues or roads with too much traffic to safely use without any other 'safe' places for me to be a dumb kid. Throw in some PTSD (related to other things) and I ate huge amounts of food that astound me now. I think if I'd been a little older, I'd have turned to drugs/alcohol/sex instead. Pretty sure I'd have preferred that. The study talking about obese people preferring to be thin and having a disability to being obese is pretty accurate in that respect.  I will also say that while exercise has recently come under a spotlight for not really doing as much for weight loss as initially thought (namely because the body changes its energy expenditure the more you exercise), food consumption is still currently one of the few ways to seriously achieve weight loss. Doctors recommending it is important. What is also *hugely* important is *how* they recommend it.   I finally got a GP properly for the first time in my life a few years ago. Her attitude is very supportive and, while she definitely tells me things I don't always like, they are never couched in a mean spirit. I feel support from her, rather than judgment. That isn't something I've encountered often when getting a doctor. It's why I bothered to actually start seeing her and talking to her about my various health concerns. Not every conversation with her leads to bringing up weight loss.   (And while it seems rational for a doctor to bring up weight loss, if every doctor you went to did it on almost every visit for anything - 'You're having breathing problems because of bronchitis after getting the flu, but you also need to lose weight.' - it would start to wear very thin. I suspect smokers have a similar issue with doctors.)

I think causation works really differently at an individual level vs a population level. If you ask why I broke my toe, it's because I decided to get drunk and see how many stairs I could jump down. If you did a study of 1000 people with toe injuries it would have a variety of causes including alcohol consumption and shoe design and running trends and increasing body weight...  The right wing tendency is to focus on individual responsibility (don't get drunk and jump down stairs) and the left wing tendency is to look at society level responsibility (can we redesign running shoes to reduce the chance of chronic injury).   Neither side is wrong. It's just different flavors of the same problem.

I think the answer lies between what provocateurs say and what you say.  Society SHOULDN'T embrace 'fat acceptance', in the sense that the fat acceptance movement does; the denial that weight and health go hand in hand, and the espousing of being fat as 'just another look' is harmful to society on every level. So losing weight is hard? Tough shit. Anything in life that's worth accomplishing is hard, and yes, it DOES boil down to 'calories in, calories out'. You're not gonna magically have more gas in the body's proverbial tank regardless of your genetics. Your body might naturally consumer fewer calories due to genetics, or more calories from the same cause, and hormones might affect that as well, but it's more a matter of adjusting at that point than gaining weight and blaming your body's natural wiring for your weight loss.  The solution is simple: be fat and happy, or lose some weight. You can be a big guy/girl/whatever you want to call yourself, but you have to know... in the pit of your stomach... that what your condition in is bad for you, and not just you, but those around you. After all, do you think your children will like knowing you might die of a heart attack or stroke before they have a chance to have children of their own? Do you think it might be less of a burden on healthcare providers (and therefore reduce costs for everyone- you included) to maintain a healthy weight and avoid obesity related illnesses?  This idea of yours that we should glorify any aspect of obesity (especially hedonism, perhaps the most empty and meaningless of ideologies) is inherently harmful.

While I agree with most things you said in this video, one thing you did overlook was the impact the obesity crisis is having on our healthcare systems. It really is costing us a fuckton of money and resources, as well as the simple fact of impaired quality of life for people struggling with obesity. What's the solution? I don't know. I think you kind of hinted on the fact that our society is basically geared towards making people fat. Perhaps severe restrictions on the availability and promotion of deeply unhealthy foods. However, we all know how much Ronald McDonald is now an American icon, so good luck getting anything like that to pass. Maybe we're just doomed to be a civilisation of fatsos.

Fat shaming is bullshit, as are those people who claim that obesity has no detrimental effects on health.  And when it comes down to pure mechanics, it is calories in/out. The yo-yo effect is a mental problem, not something your body does on its own. There are some disorders and effects of dieting that lower the amount of calories you burn, but that's in the range of maybe 300kcl. In the grand scheme of things you will lose weight if you use more calories than you consume, physiological details aside. They make a difference but not an insurmountable one. Otherwise people who live in areas afflicted by food shortages would be starving themselves fat.  The hardest part is what's going on inside your own head. Which is a real problem that can make weightloss incredibly, incredibly hard, but which doesn't mean it's a biological pipe dream, not gonna happen, why don't we just give up. As for the Milos and Katie Hopkins's of the world, they can go die in a ditch. Shame never works if you want to come out the other side a stable human being with an innate sense of self worth.

I wish people would have a little more common sense on this issue. Yes, being fat is unhealthy, but it is never okay to bully people. If you are really concerned about someone's health due to their weight, give them words of encouragement, not scorn. You are right that these people are just looking for a socially acceptable way to bully others.   Then there is the other side where people are starting to see fatness as aspirational. Being morbidly obese is no more aspirational then being a smoker or an alchoholic. It concerns me to see people throwing caution to the wayside, gaining weight carelessly, and then finding out that it wasn't such a good idea when they start to experience the negative health implications.   But above everything else, it's important to recognise that this is a systematic problem, not an individual one. The food industry, along with the social fabric, is designed in a way that makes people fat. Not everyone is going to have the genetics, education, money, socialization or will power to prevent themselves from being fat in a world that constantly bombards their senses with the smells and images of food. It's a constant battle against our survival instincts telling us we have to eat everything we see. In some ways, food is an even stronger addiction than cigarettes and alchohol because it is something you have to consume on a regular basis. How well do you think an alchoholic would do trying to quit if they had to drink at least one drink a day to survive? Obesity truly is an epidemic.

Why rather than just promote fat acceptance don't also promote working on the causes of obesity? I mean, historically it's clearly a new event (as the graphic shows), and as you said there might be many causes behind that. Let's talk about what I believe is the main cause, bad food, but it will work analogously with other cause. There is a LOT of consumption of junk food, sugar added food, trans fat food, etc. Why not to limit that amount of added sugar food can have? Why not reduce advertising of junk food? (Along with advertising with unattainable bodies). Promoting body acceptances is important but if there is not cutting on the cause then the prevalence of obesity will keep or even rise. Given that it is a health problem (we can debate about that but I believe some version of the argument still works) then we should treat it from a public policy perspective, preventing and intervening on the causes. Then given that those actions will take time promote fat acceptance as a mean to manage the fact that 30% of the population feel shame of their body. In taking a health public policy perspective I'm trying to differentiate from those you accused in the video, because they see the cause in a lack of will, lack of effort, etc, all problems within the individual action spectrum (a individualistic liberal approach).

When it comes to an increase in obesity, we should be looking at the food industry. We are bombarded with messages to drink soda every day, and it is almost always easier and cheaper to grab a soda, juice or energy drink while out of the house than it is to get water. We have an entire industry built on tricking people to eat and drink sugary, high calorie foods that are designed to be addictive, while making them easily accessible. In the face of this, how can we not have an obesity problem?

I think health is an ethical issue, as it affects everything. Eat healthier and see if you don't act kinder, spreading more love and less vitriol. See if your mental health doesn't improve when you start giving your body the nutrients it needs to operate every organ, including the brain.  (Don't respond by comparing some unhealthy nice guy to some healthy prick -- we are only in competition with ourselves; the former would be even nicer/saner if he were healthy, the latter even more cruel/wacko if he were sick.) Also, the public ends up paying higher insurance fees, not just medical but auto, as well, since sick people are more likely to be rash, confused, angry drivers. Oh, and court fees, as unhealthy people are more inclined to be criminal. Lastly, see if the environment doesn't improve, along with the cost, quality, and availability of healthy food, when more people demand organic, unprocessed foods.

And I particularly disagree with blaming others (food, society, TV, McDonald's) instead of individual behavior for obesity, given that weight is in fact mostly 'calories in, calories out.' The statement that individual behavior has nothing or little to do with obesity is plainly false and it leads to people who are already obese become more irresponsible with their health. I like that we're having this discussion, and I agree that self-harm and abuse are neither helpful nor even basically effective, let alone 'okay'... HOWEVER, the fact remains that obese people like ME and the health problems WE are uniquely disproportionately predisposed for are the single biggest chunk of extraneous cost in the ENTIRE healthcare industry. You know how America pays more per capita on healthcare than any other nation on earth by nearly an entire order of magnitude yet somehow still receives the SHITTIEST quality of care in the entire world? And yeah it DEFINITELY IS. And it's because of complications linked DIRECTLY TO OBESITY. We should NOT be normalizing fatness by creating role models specifically to be fat! Whether or not you like it, the REASON there's any value at all to be found in an epidemiological perspective on this issue is because IT *IS* AN EPIDEMIC. This shit WAS NOT HAPPENING fifty years ago! But you're right about another thing: it _isn't_ because of 'gluttony' or 'sloth'. We as a species are being *poisoned*. By what? Well remember that what makes a poison poisonous is THE DOSE. Warfarin is the same chemical as rat poison. Novacane's primary active ingredient is COCAINE. Even WATER becomes toxic past a certain LD50.   There's a chemical naturally occurring in basically every plant we can eat. It's so prevalent that our genetics have evolved to program us to seek it out by setting up an automatic dopamine response when we ingest it. We're also programmed to interpret it's flavor as 'sweet', because IN NATURE it wasa reliable signal that a plant was safe for us to eat. Nature NEVER intended for us to extract this chemical compound, concentrate it, distill it, refine it, and put ABSURDLY COPIOUS AMOUNTS OF IT IN *_EVERYTHING._* it's SUGAR. and we're eating more of it now than ever before. We're using it to override the bitter and sour signals that are supposed to tell us when something is bad for us. Ask yourself, if you have to load 30 FUCKING grams of sugar into something to make it palatable, WHY SHOULD WE BE EATING IT!? We are *abusing this substance*, and it is abusing us right back.   We bought into this insane fallacy that eating fat is what makes people fat, _succeeded_ in cutting our fat consumption in half, and proceeded to watch in horror as our population's waistlines EXPLODED. WHAT A FASCINATING CORRELATION HUH? It's because eating sugar, eating _starch,_ tells our hunter gatherer bodies that this is gathering season and winter is around the corner. The hormone that tells our cells to take on glucose for energy ALSO tells our hypothalamus to STAY HUNGRY, EAT MORE, MOVE LESS, STORE STORE STORE. Insulin. And in obese people, this whole system is past a tipping point into haywire territory.   'Fat acceptance' is going to bankrupt us, and already kills THOUSANDS of people _every single gods damned year_ from the chronic cumulative effects of obesity. For the first time since the enlightenment, life expectancy prospects have REGRESSED, and it's because of this!   Fellow obese people I implore you: do NOT give in, do NOT accept your fat, you are NOT consigned to imprisonment in this sarcophagus of adipose tissue. I PROMISE YOU, do but this ONE THING and you will reclaim your life: give your body the winter it has been preparing for over all these years. Let yourself be hungry, hunger is not persistent, it comes in waves; challenge yourself to two waves, then three, then four - FEEL your agency return to your grasp! And when you eat, reach for FAT. NOT SUGAR. We've been avoiding fat and embracing sugar all our lives and look what it's gotten us... Avoid sugar. If the nutrition label says more than 5g sugar per serving, for the love of FUCK PLEASE choose something else. Disparage carbs but glorify fiber. It isn't as hard as it sounds - this is what your body WANTS to do. Fat has insanely high satiety that comes quicker and persists for much, MUCH longer. You won't feel any lack at all. I'm a nobody and I did it, losing 50 pounds. I believe in you more than I believe in me.   Don't give up, you're not alone.

I think the main reason obesity rose was because you're classified obese by your BMI, which is body mass index. It is just your weight divided by your height. It was never made to be about individual health, it was meant to study populations with. It does not take into account what that weight is, be it fat, muscle or bone. Thus alot of people who are very healthy and don't even look fat are considered obese, people like Johnny Depp or Arnold Schwarzenegger. It is completely useless in determining how healthy you are. And the worst part? The BMI for obese used to be 45, it was changed to 30. No explanation seems to have been given, most nutritionists don't know either. It seems the reason was so that they could play up an 'obesity epidemic' and make more people think that they're unhealthy and need to buy their nutritional products. So the obesity epidemic may just be fabricated. Overall though aesthetically healthy and actually healthy are two different things. You can be very fat and healthy as long as you exercise and eat right, you could also be thin and very unhealthy if you don't. Biological health is about keeping your body well exercised and fed, not about getting a certain aesthetic.

I love you, but I think you need to have a good, long think about why thinness (and also some mildly toned muscles) is (/are) important to you and so many other people. After you've come up with some answers, or at least some theories, I think it would be beneficial for you and your viewers if you revisited this subject.  What I'm getting at is that if thin people want to stay thin and fat people want desperately to *be* thin, might not there be just a sliver of universality and--dare I say it?--truth to the notion that humans are, by nature, predisposed to find the 'ideal' body attractive? Can something of this global a scale even BE engineered (save by genetics)?  I agree that shaming fat people is pointless at best and cruel at worst. But fat epicureans are already subject to celebration so I don't see a need to further enhance their celebrity. They're already a plenty lovable archetype. I say just let people work out their issues as they see fit without any engineering in either direction.  Which brings us back to my original point and the portion of your video that I found fairly unsettling: why do you speak about your desire for thinness like it's a problem? Have you considered that maybe those desires are 'normal' (innately human, in this context) and that your seemingly negative attitude is the result of a perspective skewed (got tired of saying engineered) by the zeitgeist and the midst I imagine you find yourself in?  All of this must've sounded distinctly condescending, but all my questions were asked in the spirit of genuine inquiry and debate. So when I ask 'Have you considered...', I'm actually asking if what follows factored into your conclusions on this matter and not subtly saying 'choke on my opinions, you idiot'.

I've been overweight since I was in kindergarten. Obsessing over losing weight made me very depressed and I nearly committed suicide. I understand obesity is unhealthy but the obsession over losing the weight can cause just as much damage.

If you are Obese you are at risk of   Heart disease and stroke. High blood pressure. Diabetes. Some cancers. Gallbladder disease and gallstones. Osteoarthritis. Gout. Breathing problems, such as sleep apnea   If you are Malnourished you are at risk of   Delayed growth and development. This is especially true in children and teens, whose bodies need plenty of nutrients to grow and stay healthy. Fragile bones. ... Weakened immune system. ... Anemia. ... Fertility issues. ... Hair loss.   If you are a person that maintains a healthy diet and exercised frequently you are less likely to have to deal with any of what I just mentioned.

Can the subject of health ever be completely divorced from morality? Our health effects ourselves and those around us.  It can influence the behavior of institutions (government health care plans for example). If we are extremely obese, then this impacts our ability to take care of our own children, (and if we pass bad health habits on to our children, then we perpetuate the problem) I am not saying this to reduce the issue of obesity to health or to blame fat people for their health habits. I suppose what I'm getting at is that I don't think the relationship between health and morality/ethics can be dismissed as merely bigotry manifest.

100% agree that fat shaming is not the answer. If shaming worked, then nobody would be fat because we already shame the hell out of people as it is (especially women), and fat people generally have a ton of internalized shame already.  I do think it is possible for some people, if not many people, biologically at least to lose fat and/or gain muscle. I myself was chronically underweight at an unhealthy level and so learned all about how it works, and yes energy balance is a major factor here. That said, it is a serious commitment in time and energy, and there is billions of dollars of disinformation which ultimately just confuses the fuck out of everyone in terms of how to actually do it. If everyone had all the right information, it should still be matter of personal preference and none of anyone else's business. And even then, it's a matter of changing all sorts of unconscious habits which are being continually shaped by multi-national food corporations and marketing and the design of our environments, all of which is incredibly difficult to change on one's own.  I do think we have ethical duties to do a small amount of exercise and to look after our own health, because no one else can do it, because it can cause harm or benefit to a human being worthy of care, and because our own health habits also inevitably affect others. But I don't think that looks like more than an hour or two a week of moving one's body, trying to cut back on one's addictions, and eating some veggies once in a while. And ultimately health and appearance are rather unrelated variables in any case. Bodybuilders are often very unhealthy -- it's not unheard of for someone to die on stage of a heart attack. The weight loss and fitness communities are full of disordered eating and exercising behaviors that are sources of self-harm and obsession. It is rare to find someone who has struck a healthy balance with all this stuff, and I think it's worth seeking, but certainly not something to impose upon others.  If anything, we should think about how to structure societies such that more movement is built in to our environments (e.g. bike lanes and walking malls), and more health food options are available to underserved communities (e.g. urban gardens).

I'm slightly overweight because I have hypothyroidism (not enough thyroxin=slow metabolism, tiredness, dry skin, etc.). The ironic thing is that my doctor thinks that because of my history of anorexia and bulimia, my thyroid function started to slow down during the period of my life when I was severely underweight, starving myself, and later binging and purging because my body has probably developed metabolic mechanisms of keeping on as much weight as possible ever since. I'm not fat(-ish) because I'm greedy and indulgent, I'm fat(-ish) because I was told almost from childhood that the main concern when we eat and exercise should be how we look and how attractive (read: skinny) we are, which caused me to be *too* disciplined and restrictive. The advice that these shitlords are giving couldn't be more counter-productive, not just because it may affect people in the same way it did me, but because restricting what you eat in any way can cause some people to binge eat if they get upset and restless about how they look and are super-consciously ashamed of how they got that way. My usual impression when I hear someone giving 'advice' like this is that they probably have either a faster metabolism, a greater sense of self-control, or just don't really care either way about food, and therefore they probably haven't experienced the same issues as the people in question. Yes, being overweight or obese is definitely not good for you, but there isn't any effort on the part of these people to consider biological or psychological factors. It's not 'acceptance' or 'being a pussy', it's the most logical and constructive way to address such a widespread and often life-threatening problem. There's just no fucking empathy.

While I get your point, I have an observation: while most of the factors you described aren't American-only, the percentage of overweight (or above) people in America is rather distant from the (statistical) norm for other rich countries. Given this, don't you think acceptance is a temporary solution, and possibly hindering for people (as in 'can't do anything about it' or the rather more obviously false 'everything's fine, I'm only above 250 kg, on a 1.60 metre frame')? Wouldn't something akin to sex-ed about nutrition and general self care (in the 'caring for your body, as any machine it too needs judicious use') be more productive? Particularly as this could also be use to ward people against other possible risks (insane self-styled diets, workout regiment, the likes). Thank you.

So in my quest as an anti-SJW to go through your backlog of videos, I have chosen this as my next experience. As always the skit bits are hilarious and I love them and want them framed (idk how it'd work, but we'll make it work) I totally agree with you that fat-shaming at least borders on, if not being outright, bullying. It's not necessary, and while it make work in SOME cases, it seems to often do more harm than good. Now what I can not get behind is the idea that we should just accept obesity. And i'm saying this as someone who is somewhere between overweight and obese. There are a myriad of health problems that come with being overweight and obese, and we really shouldn't encourage people to live in a way that is unhealthy for them. We don't encourage people to be alcoholics, or to smoke constantly. We don't bully and shame them either, to be fair. Even if there are factors other than just a lack of self control and discipline that goes into obesity, there is also mountains of proof that you can lose weight and keep it off if you work hard enough and make smart eating choices. That does NOT mean you'll look like a model, but you will be healthy and avoid weight-related health complications. And regardless of how hard it is to get healthy, I cannot get behind simply accepting fatness because it's hard to keep it in check.  Now I do agree that not everyone is a model, and the 'beauty standard' for women AND men is pretty unattainable. We should celebrate a diverse set of body types, and you can be healthy without being a 120 pound stickman (or stickwoman as the case may be) Overall I loved the video and I can't wait to look into more of your work! :D

The concept of being unable to control my body weight is almost alien to me. I understand that my cultivated and informed self-restraint takes a fair amount consistent effort, and that many people choose to forego this in favor of more immediate pleasures. Well constructed video, I liked. But I would like to question what you say in part 3: fat acceptance. (It is going to be quite long, sorry about that... thank you very much to anybody who will read the entire thing).  First of all, let's clarify something: I hate fat. Not fat people: my loath is only directed toward that yellow thing and the moral burden it embodies. And I know that my desire to stay the healthiest possible and thus in shape (not skinny, in shape) comes from a very subjective set of moral and philosophical principles (the behavioral tags I chose...and vanity is also to blame...). I just wanted to make that bias clear before starting.  So my main issue concerns your point about the 'moralizing edge to the idea of health'. Of course, and I totally agree with you on that principle, it is not 'inherently virtuous to be healthy' (there is no such thing as Universal Virtue anyway) but in a society that aims to implement a truly fonctional healthcare system, a national responsibility is to be waited from each individuals (to go further: metabo law in Japan). Because of the material (money, infrastructures...) and human consequences of a certain type of behavior: your liberty ceases where my liberty begins. And if the egoistic decisions you take are dangerous to the equilibrium of society (considering that the majority agrees with this type of equilibrium) then the expected outcome is to see yourself being dismissed or ostracized. However, I do believe that everything is a question of structure, we are all rolling stones in the river (Spinoza, my love) and we shouldn't put all the blame on the responsibility of obese people towards food.  - First there is 'environmental structure': part of it is the fact that it is way easier and cheaper to buy junk food in the USA than it is in France for example. In France you can buy your vegetables for a reasonable price at supermarkets or 'open air markets' (both cases tested)... fresh food was much more expensive in the USA...(=>Income inequalities related obesity) The problem is multiple in fact, from urban design (too many fast food restaurants, not enough supermarkets), to the food industry, wealth inequalities, antibiotics... - Then there is 'mental structure': victimization is a cancer because it bears the germ of resignation. And this state of mind comes from the general passiveness that seem to be commonly widespread today...I hope that's just my feeling though.  But let's come back to Fat acceptance: Loving yourself, yes, but in order to strive to become better. I am not saying that skinny is superior to fat (superior in terms of what ?), I am saying that to live as fully as possible, there is nothing better than feeling the burning flame of that desire to surpass themselves (well that's what I believe). And thus do what is possible to maintain the full capacities of one's body.  And finally, I have some (ethical and moral) issues with the idea of viewing fatness as a celebration of excess and thus as something positive (especially from the 'biological beauty/best offspring-related choice' point of view)... but this paragraph is getting too long :)  Sorry again for the length... Love :)

This 'lingering anxiety' you describe? That's called 'fear'. You know why fear exists? To keep you from making very poor decisions. Vertigo exists to keep you from falling to your death. 'Conquering' these fears doesn't necessarily make you 'brave' or 'strong' - it just means you've retarded an instinct that was otherwise meant to be used for self-preservation. Although I don't usually agree with you on many things (I'm a subscriber because I find your videos entertaining and to listen to a different point of view so I don't live in an echo chamber), I do agree with this video a lot.  One thing that the anti-fat-positivity people fail to understand is that, like you said, there are MANY, MANY factors that make people fat. There's the whole sugar industry conspiracy that was a big contributor to the obesity epidemic and other things like diseases, genetics, mental health etc. As someone who's somewhat fat not because I have some sort of disease like Hypothyroidism and who's lost a lot of weight in the past and have put everything on again, I can tell you that losing weight isn't easy, it's VERY, VERY hard. It requires A LOT of discipline and motivation. Especially when food with high concentration of fat and sugar is so widely available and cheap. Add depression to the mix and then you have a recipe for disaster. It's really hard not to eat or drink when you are depressed as those are two of the few things that bring some sort of pleasure or make you forget about things. Because of all of that I'm against fat-shaming and the whole tough-love thing.  I just have a few problems with the fat acceptance movement. One is that it makes it seem like that being fat is healthy when it's not. I've seen people in the movement claiming that doctors are lying when they say that obesity increase your risk factors, it isn't healthy and when they say that they are fat-shaming. NO, being fat isn't healthy and I know I'm not healthy. You should like yourself for what you are, but knowing that you body isn't in a healthy state (even if you have low cholesterol and a good diet) and know the dangers being fat brings. We should fight the obesity epidemic not because it's not attractive, but because obesity is dangerous while of course accepting people for who they are. There are many ways to do that, including educating people about what types of food or habits are healthy.  Another problem I have with it is that the movement is too focused on women to the point that many of them don't give a shit about fat men. You could argue that women have more expectations from society when it comes to image, I'll grant you that, but men are seen as lazy and dirty when they are fat as much as women and I've seen many, many men who struggle with body image as well and are told to suck it up.  Also some people in the movement (and I have to emphasize here that it's not everyone) sound like they are saying that women shouldn't accept that some men won't feel attracted to them because they are fat and that those men should be ashamed of themselves for being so superficial but with fat guys it's a different story. I've been rejected many times for superficial reasons and I do understand and accept that not everyone will be be attracted to me and they don't have to, and those people have to understand that women should accept that's gonna happen to them too.  I don't know, this is basically my view, feel free to disagree or whatever.

The reality is that the 'weight loss' industry is inherently bad because they've marketed weight loss as a product to buy and not something to work toward. Juxtaposing yourself against a bunch of ass hats doesn't make what you have to say next any more true. So let's set aside the deliberately outrageous provocateurs and see if what you're saying makes any sense in its own right.  Your last point speaks against your thesis. You've spent the whole video saying, in effect, people are gonna be what they're gonna be, so let's just accept it and celebrate it. But then you admit that you feel the desire to be thin, based on vanity. Vanity is generally frowned upon. But it's a natural human impulse. Why not direct it towards a pro social outcome? We could probably agree that vanity should be diminished. And thus we can dismiss the bullies who revel in vanity and thus encourage it. But I don't think it's feasible to think that we can remove vanity from the human experience.  If we're stuck with vanity, why not channel it towards a healthy body? We're fat as a population. And that's a real health problem. But at lest we don't want to be. Claiming that we should just accept being fat seems like throwing in the towel. It's sour grapes. Ceasing to want something (health) because we've found that we can't get it. Because whatever we do to try and address being fat, it doesn't work.  I would rather look for something that does work, than just accept the miserable state of things as they are. That celebration seems hollow.

Although I agree with your main premise that fat shaming is both immoral and counterproductive from a public health standpoint, I disagree with your statement that obesity should be celebrated as a symbol of glorious excess.  This idea dishonestly represents the distribution of obesity within developed countries, and ignores the disease burden that our society saddles on low-income people.  Within developed countries, obesity does not represent access to calories.  Rather, it represents a LACK of access to healthy foods, places to conveniently and safely exercise, and critically, a lack of leisure time with which to prepare food at home and exercise.  As a result, obese people are disproportionately poor and live in poor neighborhoods.  Low-income people disproportionately suffer from obesity-related diseases such as heart disease and diabetes, and simultaneously lack the resources to effectively treat them.  This is a critical social justice issue that should not be ignored in the name of body positivity.

The morality of self-harm is such a debatable topic. If we lived in an ideal universe where each person had perfect self-control and knew just how much of something would cause them more harm than good, it would certainly be morally acceptable to engage in any activity (even those generally thought of as 'bad for you') that only involved one's self. But in reality, we possess neither comprehensive knowledge nor sufficient self-control, and therefore actions that can offer immediate pleasure may be, unbeknownst to us, causing us more harm than good either presently or further down the road. Is it morally required of us to err on the side of caution even to the detriment of our current happiness? And is it our job to punish those who do not follow this moral requirement with negative social interaction?

I was wondering if you were planning to address the counter of the 'fat shaming' people, that is, the side of the fat acceptance movement that goes into outright denial of obesity as a physical health problem.  It is a health problem, and while it does have significant environmental and genetic causes, that does not mean that we can't or shouldn't do anything about it at the social or policy level.  For instance, the obesity epidemic is driven in large part by the fact that many people simply do not have the financial means to buy healthy food. That means that an entire social class of people is forced into having the long-term health problems and lower overall quality of life that come with being obese.  It's not as if obese people are making the choice to be obese, clearly given the choice they would not actually want to be, nor would they want their children to be, but they are simply not being given the option to not be obese.  That is something that we can solve without shaming anyone.  It's just like any other disease.  You shouldn't be made to feel bad for something that's out of your control (and in fact studies show that feelings of shame hinder rather than help a person recover from obesity), but you only make things worse if you stray into denial that the disease exists.

I think you're right that people are often too quick to judge fat people as lazy. But when you say things like, 'individuals do have some control over their weight', I think you're going a bit far in the other direction. Let's be honest, people have full control in losing weight if they choose to. And doing so would be beneficial to society.  A 'celebration of excess' seems so stupid to me. Would we have a celebration of people suffering a drug or alcohol addiction? What about a celebration of depression? We recognise that although these situations might not be as simple to fix as calling someone stupid or lazy, they're certainly not ideal and we shouldn't accept it.  I think there should be more help for people with all these issues. I'm not so sure about the USA, but in the UK obesity is a huge issue for the NHS. The more obese people we have in society the more people we have not paying taxes, while also taking more out of the health service. I think being understanding but firm as a society is a sensible position.  Also, at the end of your video you mention you want to look healthy. Why do you think that is? When I was 20 I used to be addicted to fitness and exercise, and a huge driver in that was because I wanted to be accepted. I had the opposite problem, people calling me too skinny, but if I was accepted for that I probably wouldn't be a healthier weight now. And perhaps you wouldn't want to look healthy either? Can you see how not completely accepting obesity without being a dickhead isn't such as awful thing?  Enjoyed video though, you're massively undersubbed for how good your production is.

I think the point the 'trolls' are trying to make is that displaying awful ideas publicly isn't an attempt to provoke a rational counterargument, but is rather intended to draw out people who use violence or legislated censorship as a means to win an argument, and provoke them to openly make an ass of themselves by doing so - that is, when it is 'trolling' and not someone's actual opinion. An atmosphere of open controversy is supposed to make us think about how we go about 'winning' arguments. I mean, Contra poking fun at trolls is hilarious but it isn't actually in line with the Socratic method,which involves a dialogue in which questions are raised to discover an opponents premises, exposing them as true or false. Nor does it particularly invested in parallel debate, where outcome is set aside in favor of obtaining the maximum amount of information before deciding upon a correct conclusion. So oddly enough the bit where the shamers criticize others for criticizing them is actually a valid concern. Arguments aren't 'won' simply by exposing their conclusions as false. They are won by forming and promoting counterarguments which use new premises and syllogisms to suggest a conclusion which is actually true. Contra does this with data, and that's the actual counterargument. It would be a mistake to view the critique of the trolls as at all relevant to the outcome of the debate.  I mean it's funny, but it isn't an argument and shouldn't be viewed as such by trolls or anyone else.

The 'concern expressed through insults' angle has always been bullshit.  If the shamers were really concerned about overweight people's health, and not just their dislike of overweight bodies on aesthetic grounds, then why aren't they insulting anyone who smokes or drinks in the same way?  They just want an excuse to be cruel and horrible, then to feel ethically justified in retrospect.  As for overweight female role models from children's media, Rose Quartz from Steven Universe?

I do generally tend towards the 'fuck it!  health damage be damned do what gives your miserable existence a bit of levity' standpoint, but the counterargument that such a cavalier attitude towards health would serve to burden a socialized healthcare system, something else I support, does make accepting it wholeheartedly a bit difficult.  Drinking and smoking obviously have this same affect, but I believe that the paranoia of 'am I getting screwed by paying more than I'd need to because these people are less healthy than me' is overall one of the biggest hurdles for socialized medicine to clear.
